remarks: Finite version of dependent choice.  Construct a function whose value depends on the previous function value, except at a final point at which no new value can be chosen.  The final hypothesis ensures that the process will terminate.  The proof does not use the Axiom of Choice. (Contributed by Jeff Madsen, 18-Jun-2010.)
statement:
fdc.1 $e |- A e. _V $.
fdc.2 $e |- M e. ZZ $.
fdc.3 $e |- Z = ( ZZ>= ` M ) $.
fdc.4 $e |- N = ( M + 1 ) $.
fdc.5 $e |- ( a = ( f ` ( k - 1 ) ) -> ( ph <-> ps ) ) $.
fdc.6 $e |- ( b = ( f ` k ) -> ( ps <-> ch ) ) $.
fdc.7 $e |- ( a = ( f ` n ) -> ( th <-> ta ) ) $.
fdc.8 $e |- ( et -> C e. A ) $.
fdc.9 $e |- ( et -> R Fr A ) $.
fdc.10 $e |- ( ( et /\ a e. A ) -> ( th \/ E. b e. A ph ) ) $.
fdc.11 $e |- ( ( ( et /\ ph ) /\ ( a e. A /\ b e. A ) ) -> b R a ) $.
fdc $p |- ( et -> E. n e. Z E. f ( f : ( M ... n ) --> A /\ ( ( f ` M ) = C /\ ta ) /\ A. k e. ( N ... n ) ch ) ) $.
$d A a b f n $.
$d C f n $.
$d M a b f k n $.
$d N a b f k n $.
$d R a b $.
$d Z a b n $.
$d a b ch n $.
$d a b et $.
$d a b ta $.
$d a ps $.
$d f k ph $.
$d f n th $.
